Let me tell you about this truly awful game company, one that seems to have no regard for its players except for how much money it can squeeze out of them. They have recently released Overwatch 2 as a free to play business model, but don't be fooled, my friend. This new model is filled to the brim with microtransactions, overpriced skins, and downright predatory behavior.

But wait, it gets even worse. They have actually shut down the first game, rendering it completely unplayable for all those who had purchased it. Can you believe that? They simply expect the entire playerbase to migrate over to this free to play model if they want to continue enjoying the game. It's a blatant disregard for their loyal customers and a clear money grab.

Now, you might be thinking, "Well, at least they promised a PvE Hero mode with character progression, right?" Wrong! Just when you thought there might be a glimmer of hope, they go ahead and cancel that too. Can you believe the audacity? It's as if they're actively trying to disappoint and deceive their players.

But fear not, dear gamer. They do offer a lighter story mission for the low, low price of $15. How generous of them, right ? But it's a shame that they wouldn't just give the players what they wanted in the first place. In any case, we can only hope that the gaming industry will learn from this experience and be more transparent with their players in the future. Companies should be more willing to provide content that their customers are willing to pay for, without resorting to tactics like these. Additionally, they should be more open and honest about their pricing structure, so players don't feel like they're being taken advantage of. Just think of how much more money the gaming industry would make if they simply asked players for their opinion on what content they'd like to pay for, instead of resorting to these underhanded tactics!

I bought Overwatch in late 2016, right around when Ana was released as a playable hero. At first, I was skeptical, since I was coming off of playing thousands of hours of TF2, so I was particularly embedded in the hate culture surrounding this game. Though, against my better judgement, I bought the Origins Edition of the game around my birthday. I played it, the game was decent, and eventually I started finding out people in my friend group had the game too. I played it with them, as well as on my own for hours out of a day, and ended up falling in love with the style and cast of characters.

Uprising came out in 2017. It was a PVE version of the game, it cemented my appreciation for Overwatch, as someone who does on occasion enjoy PVE experiences. To see what was essentially a shortened version of MvM in a game like Overwatch increased my hope that more events like this would happen in the future, and many of them did. I missed the first Junkenstein, but on it's return in 2017, I had a blast. When Uprising got a new release, I played it. I often would spend days trying to get all of the achievements, though I was ultimately unsuccessful as I had school to attend, and was otherwise preoccupied.

I played plenty of competitive as well, though I never played enough to get a gold weapon (I was 200 points away from one when I stopped playing competitive), I still enjoyed my time trying to cooperate with my team. In my early years of playing overwatch, I mained soldier 76 and tracer, though as time went on I played a more supportive role. I still enjoyed the game considerably through 2017, especially when Moira came out. Ana and Lucio were my mains, though I often gravitated towards Moira when I wanted to lay out serious hurt. Those were the days.

Not long after, me and my significant other started playing overwatch together. We never played any competitive, since she was never really interested in the competitive side of the game. We played often, we were the perfect support duo. And in 2019, I mustered the courage to ask her to be my girlfriend on the junkenstein 2019 main menu screen. We're still together.

We started to play the game less and less. My friends had moved on from the game, it was just me and my significant other playing, and we were still enjoying the experience. We played the new Storm Rising event when it came out, but I believe I only played it once. My interest was weighing, and so was hers. Though, that changed when we caught wind of a possible 'Overwatch 2' on the horizon. Me and my significant other were excited, even hopeful about the potential for something new, something interesting coming to Overwatch, And, since me and her were both heavily interested in PVE game modes, when we heard it was going to be potentially very PVE based, we couldn't wait to see what Blizzard had in store.

So, we waited. And we waited. To keep myself occupied, I played the 2020 challenges to get the new limited time skins. Things used to be free. I started losing interest again as the years dragged on, and so did my significant other. Then, we started hearing news of employees fleeing the team. We watched Mccree become Cassidy, we watched Jeff Kaplan leave Blizzard. When Overwatch 2 finally came out, we took one look at the Sombra clown skin we were awarded for owning Overwatch, and all of the micro-transactions, the battle pass and the false promises. That day, we told ourselves we would never play Overwatch again. We never would be able to, that much was lied about. All of the time spent, the hours leveling, the years unlocking skins and honing our heroes' skills. When Overwatch 2 came out, we felt like the Sombra clown skin, we were the clowns. This game has thoroughly wasted our time, and is desperately trying to waste yours as well. Stay far away from this title.

The developers of this game molested a female employee so fvcking bad that she took her own life. And then they go and cancel PvE on us afterwards. This woman literally ended her own life for nothing. Rest in peace, madam.

To the overwatch fans: This is is not a review bombing from TF2 fans. 

Overwatch was a game with promise, a bit lacking in features and game modes but people really loved it. All it needed was support. Instead all it got was lootboxes, a few additional heroes, and a few additional maps. Then we were promised all the content that should've been added to Overwatch in a sequel called Overwatch 2. What was actually added? Additional monetization in an effort to nickle and dime every cent they can from people. Nothing new has been added to this game. A few more maps, a few more heroes, and a few copy pasted pve events that they've been rolling out temporarily every few years.

There's no love behind this game, no passion, no art, nothing. It's a soulless husk being squeezed for every penny that it can and it's completely worthless. Twenty years later people still remember games like Unreal Tournament. In twenty years nothing will be remembered of Overwatch but porn.

Blizzard just had to do one thing to save this IP. 
Make. PvE. Free.

After canceling the replayability and Hero Missions, that was the least they could've done but no. We now have a 80‚Ç¨ purchase option on the steam release, for a free-to-play game. This is just insulting, blizzard didnt change at all

Gameplay is as bad as ever, Matchmaker is unbalanced and still prefers shorter queue times over a qualitative match up.
New heros still paywalled and overpowered.

I would never recommend this game. I used to love it ,i was paassionate about it, but Blizzard killed Ow1 for this overpromised, underdelivered, parody of a Ow1. I will never forgive Blizzard for killing the only game i truly cared for. Rest In Peace Overwatch. You will not be forgotten.
"Blizzard tore our families apart"
                                -Winton Overwat
